Title: Contribution of information technology through consumer engagement to improve market growth of credit union
Source title: 2017 5th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management, CITSM 2017
Affiliations: STMIK Pontianak, Pontianak, Indonesia; Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gat, STMIK Pontianak, Pontianak, Indonesia; Abdurahman, E., Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia; Waworuntu, S.R., Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Credit Union (CU) cooperative in West Kalimantan continues to experience significant growth as one of the democracy strength. As a financial institution in the form of cooperative, the credit union had owned and controlled by the members who use its services. Professional management had made CU stronger with regard to solidarity aspect of the stakeholders in it. The use of information technology for service activity in order to keep the solidarity, members also had participated in the growth of the Credit Union, but there are some values of contribution that still unknown, such as the contribution of information technology and the participation of members. The research problem formulated to (a) produce new research on the influence of IT innovation, IT resource, IT service and the involvement of consumer in enhancing business growth; (B) create a hypothetical test design in order to know the influence of each variable in this research. This research aims to produce model and hypothetical test design to recognize the influence of IT innovation, IT resource, IT service and consumer involvement in enhancing business growth. This research was designed with unit explanatory survey that analyzed by organization. Furthermore, this research applied mixed methods (quantitative and qualitative) and triangulation strategy. The sample included 58 Credit Union is measured by using the formula Slovin. Credit Union (CU) determined by simple random sampling technique because it is based on the contribution of information technology and consumer involvement in business growth. This study only produces a research proposal model without providing results that illustrate the role of information technology and empirical consumer involvement. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Business Growth; Consumer Engagement; IT Innovation; IT Resource; IT Service
Index Keywords: Business growth; Consumer Engagement; IT innovation; IT resources; IT services

Title: Determinants of transfer pricing aggressiveness in Indonesia
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Waworuntu, S.R., Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia; Hadisaputra, R., Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia
Abstract: The objective of this empirical research is to examine the major determinants of transfer pricing aggressiveness in Indonesia. This research used a sample of multinational companies listed in the Indonesian Stock Exchange (IDX) from the period of 2010 to 2012. The data analysis was based on the company's financial statements generated from the IDX. Transfer pricing aggressiveness was measured by TPRICE index, which consists of items that represent occurrences of non-arm's length transactions. Six determinants of transfer pricing aggressiveness were tested in this study, including firm size, profitability, leverage, intangible assets, multi-nationality and tax haven utilisation. To test the model, multiple regression analysis was applied. Based on the results, the authors discovered that firm size and leverage are positively associated with transfer pricing aggressiveness, while intangible assets and multi-nationality are negatively associated. This study also shows that profitability and tax haven utilisation are not related to transfer pricing aggressiveness. © 2016 Universiti Putra Malaysia Press.
Author Keywords: Arm's length principle; Indonesia; Tax avoidance; Transfer pricing

Authors: Rusmanto T., Waworuntu S.R., Nugraheny H.
Title: Lead-lag effects in stock returns: Evidence from indonesia
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia; Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara International University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Rusmanto, T., Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia; Waworuntu, S.R., Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara International University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia; Nugraheny, H., Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara International University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia
Abstract: The main purpose of this research is to determine the existence of lead-lag effects in stock returns in the Indonesia Stock Exchange. Fifty-eight companies were taken as samples, selected through industrial classification and selection criteria of leader and follower stocks. The data is analysed using Vector Auto Regression method to extrapolate and investigate the existence of lead-lag effects in Indonesian capital market. This study finds that returns to stocks with relatively high market capitalizations lead returns to stocks with relatively low market capitalizations in Indonesian industry portfolios. However, out of ten industries, there are only six who contribute significant result. This research concludes that lead-lag effects do exist in certain industries and it may assist investors in managing the trading strategy. Indonesian capital market is not efficient since lead-lag effects is one of the phenomenon, which against the EMH.
Author Keywords: Cross-correlation; Indonesia Stock Exchange; Lead-lag effects; Stock Returns
References: Boudoukh, J., Richardson, M.P., Whitelaw, R.F., Tale of three schools: Insights of autocorrelations of short-horizon stock returns (1995) Review of Financial Studies, 7 (3), pp. 539-573; Conrad, J., Kaul, G., Time variation in expected returns (1988) The Journal of Business, 61 (4), pp. 409-425; Fama, E., Permanent and temporary components of stock prices (1988) Journal of Political Economy, 96 (2), pp. 246-273; Fama, E.F., Efficient capital market, II (1991) The Journal of Finance, 46 (5), pp. 1575-1617; Gultekin, M.N., Gultekin, N.B., Stock market seasonality: International evidence (1983) Journal of Financial Economics, 12 (4), pp. 469-481; Haque, T., Lead-lag effects in Australian industry portfolios (2010) The Journal of Finance, 18 (3), pp. 267-290; Hou, K., Industry information diffusion and the lead-lag effects in stock returns (2007) Review of Financial Studies, 20 (4), pp. 1113-1138; Lo, A., Mackinlay, A., When are contrarian profits due to stock market overreaction? Authors: Rusmanto T., Waworuntu S.R., Tjeuw J.
Title: Integration analysis’ explanatory power over stock returns: Evidence from Indonesia
Affiliations: Binus Business School, Binus University, Jakarta, 12070, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Rusmanto, T., Binus Business School, Binus University, Jakarta, 12070, Indonesia; Waworuntu, S.R., Binus Business School, Binus University, Jakarta, 12070, Indonesia; Tjeuw, J., Binus Business School, Binus University, Jakarta, 12070, Indonesia
Abstract: The main purpose of this research is to identify whether integration analysis for stock returns has higher predictive power compared to technical analysis and fundamental analysis alone based on research conducted in Indonesia. To fulfill the objective, the “blue chip” Indonesian companies are chosen. The research data period is 2007–2011 and taken quarterly. Technical analysis uses previous quarter return to predict current quarter returns. Fundamental analysis uses operating cash flow and price-to-book ratio. Integrated analysis combines these three variables to test the combined predictive power over current quarter stock returns. The results are compared using multiple regression analysis. Change in price-to-book ratio is significant and can help predict stock returns while previous quarter returns do not have predictive power of the next quarter returns, possibly due to the volatility in Indonesian market. Operating cash flow, while important, does not have predictive power over stock returns, possibly due to it not being an important factor in making investment decisions in Indonesia. Potential investors should understand Price-to-Book ratio and use it in any analysis concerning stock returns. They should also be prudent not to make investment decisions based on historical stock returns. Operating cash flow-generating ability is not one of the indicators the market watches out for. Integrated analysis outperforms a purely technical analysis, but not a purely fundamental analysis. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fundamental; Integrated analysis; Stock return; Technical
References: Bettman, J.L., Sault, S.J., Schultz, E.L., (2009) Accounting and Finance, 49, p. 21; Fama, E.F., Blume, M., (1996) Journal of Business, 39, p. 226; Liu, W., Strong, N., Xu, X., (1999) Journal of Business Finance and Accounting, 26, p. 1043; Jegadeesh, N., Titman, S., (1993) The Journal of Finance, 48, p. 65; Arena, M.P., Haggard, K.S., Yan, X., (2008) The Financial Review, 43, p. 159; Bonenkamp, U., Homburg, C., Kempf, A., (2011) Journal of Business Finance and Accounting, 38, p. 842; Alesii, G., (2006) International Journal of Business and Economics, 5, p. 245; Fama, E.F., French, K.R., (1992) The Journal of Finance, 57, p. 427; Margaretha, F., Damayanti, I., (2008) Jurnal Bisnis Dan Akutansi, 10, p. 149; Waworuntu, S.R., Suryanto, H., (2010) Jurnal Manajemen Bisnis, 3, p. 167; Clinch, G., Sidhu, B., Sing, S., (2002) Review of Accounting Studies, 7, p. 383; Habib, A., (2010) Australian Accounting Review, 20, p. 134; Penman, S., Richardson, S., Tuna, I., (2005) University of Pennsylvania, p. 5; Kim, M., Kross, W., (2005) Journal of Accounting Research, 43, p. 753
